awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research with Ethical, Legal and Social Implications
awd_abstract_narration: With the increasing use of autonomous systems in society, such as self-driving vehicles, issues of ethics becomes paramount.  The proposal seeks to bring researchers in AI and Robotics together with researchers in ethics and the law to discuss the relationships between research in ethical, legal and social implications (ELSI) and research in technological development and design.  The focus of the workshop will be both on the ethics and legality of using autonomous systems and on how to imbue autonomous systems with a set of ethical behaviors.  The workshop will discuss the issues and how NSF can promote interdisciplinary work between technologists and ethicists in the ELSI arena.  Approximately 30 researchers in AI, robotics, ethics and the law, together with regulators and industrial people from the automotive industry will be invited.  The one-day format, which will be held at Stanford University, will include lightning talks by participants, several breakout sessions, and work towards an executive summary and electronic reference guide on ?best practices? for such collaborative research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the development of a workshop on fostering interdisciplinary work involving researchers from law, ethics, social sciences and engineering.  The workshop was held at Stanford University on August 7, 2017 and included participants from industry, academia and government.  The grant supported travel costs for some remote participants and others, including NSF staff participated remotely from the east coast.  The workshop consisted of some opening talks followed by a series of breakout discussions around the topics of Rewards and Success Factors; Obstacles and Challenges; Institutional Recommendations; and Recommendations for Researchers.  Participants recorded the discussion of each breakout group with key observations shared among groups.  

The discussions identified three specific mechanisms researchers should consider to facilitate interdisciplinary work in these fields:

Embedded researchers - The medical field has demonstrated the effectiveness of having ethicists embedded in a clinical setting to help health care providers and patients work through decisions with ethical dimensions.  Similarly, mechanisms such as AAAS Fellowships exist that enable engineers and social scientists to embed into government agencies and policy-making settings.  These models could be extended more broadly to enable researchers in engineering, law, social science and ethics to embed in other settings.  Embedding provides the researcher a chance to learn about the questions and challenges faced in this setting while providing the host group with insight from the research discipline.  Thinking broadly, host organizations can include university departments or research groups; corporations; government agencies; NGOs; and medical facilities.  While the experience can be designed as largely observational, potentially greater benefits come through establishing a clear role and objectives for the embedded researcher.  Developments in design methodology prove useful here in providing mechanisms for the social sciences to closely connect with even highly technical design processes.  For instance, Value Sensitive Design offers a framework through which researchers familiar with human values can help identify the values important to a particular design and help close the gap between values and design requirements. 

Focused deliverables - Working across disciplines can be challenging for a number of reasons, not least of which is the fact that different disciplines expect or reward different forms of scholarly output.  The relative value of a conference paper, journal paper or book (to say nothing of less traditional forms such as film, clinical outcomes or influence on an engineering design) varies widely across disciplines.  As a result, identifying the deliverables or expected work product at the start of a project can be helpful to ensure the collaboration makes sense for all involved.  In addition, putting the focus of a project on the deliverable can help to provide a concrete shared goal around which the group can form.  One example cited was a project examining the technical, social and legal aspects of autonomous vehicles facilitated by the Daimler and Benz Foundation.  This project involved a series of workshops for the exchange of ideas with the ultimate goal of producing an open access book.  The book ultimately became the publisher?s most downloaded book, demonstrating the potential for wide dissemination with the proper choice of deliverable.   

Research networks - Researchers in different disciplines have, in general, chosen careers because of an interest or affinity for the problems and methods central to the discipline.  While individuals may find a lasting identity at the intersection of disciplines, identifying as a medical ethicist or a robotics ethicist, for instance, this tends to be the exception rather than the norm.  Instead, interdisciplinary work may be more transient as a researcher?s interests overlap with a new discipline while addressing a particular question or project.  To best facilitate this type of work, the research community could facilitate the process of finding collaborators across disciplines who have an interest in such interdisciplinary cooperation.  Since researchers may be interested in collaboration around specific projects, a network structure has an advantage over facilitating pair-wise connections between researchers.  Such a network would enable researchers in specific disciplines to readily connect with others who appreciate the importance of interdisciplinary work to cooperate on a specific project and return to their discipline or connect with other disciplines upon completion.  The discussion around this approach highlighted that collaborations need not be lengthy or ongoing in order to be meaningful and impactful.
